sn35.94:1.2: “Bhikkhus, these six contact-fields bring suffering when they are untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:1.4: The contact-field of the eye brings suffering when it is untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:1.5: The contact-field of the ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.94:1.6: The contact-field of the mental faculty brings suffering when it is untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:1.7: These six contact-fields bring suffering when they are untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:2.1: These six contact-fields bring happiness when they are well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
sn35.94:2.3: The contact-field of the eye brings happiness when it is well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
sn35.94:2.4: The contact-field of the ear … nose… tongue … body …
sn35.94:2.5: The contact-field of the mental faculty brings happiness when it is well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
sn35.94:2.6: These six contact-fields bring happiness when they are well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.”
sn35.94:2.7: That is what the Buddha said.
sn35.94:2.8: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn35.94:3.1: “Bhikkhus, it is just these six contact-fields
sn35.94:3.2: where one unrestrained meets with suffering.
sn35.94:3.3: Those who understand how to restrain them
sn35.94:4.3: subdue all manner of desire for the pleasant,
sn35.94:4.4: and do not pollute the mind with thoughts of antipathy.
sn35.94:5.1: When you hear sounds both agreeable and disagreeable,
sn35.94:5.2: do not become enthralled with agreeable sounds,
sn35.94:5.3: and subdue aversion for the disagreeable.
sn35.94:5.4: Do not pollute the mind with thoughts of antipathy.
sn35.94:6.1: When you smell a fragrant, delightful scent,
sn35.94:6.2: and one that is foul and unpleasant,
sn35.94:6.4: and do not yield to desire for the pleasant.
sn35.94:7.1: When partaking of a sweet, delicious taste,
sn35.94:7.2: and sometimes, those that are bitter,
sn35.94:7.3: do not partake of the sweet taste fixated on it,
sn35.94:7.4: and do not despise the bitter.
sn35.94:8.1: Do not become infatuated with a pleasant pressure
sn35.94:8.2: and do not tremble at an unpleasant one.
sn35.94:8.3: Look with equanimity at the duality of pleasant and painful pressures,
sn35.94:9.1: People generally let their perceptions proliferate;
sn35.94:9.2: perceiving and proliferating, they become engaged.
sn35.94:9.3: Expel all thoughts concerned with the mundane,
sn35.94:9.4: and go about intent on renunciation.
sn35.94:10.1: When the mind is well developed like this with regard to the six,
sn35.94:10.2: it does not waver at all in face of pressure.
sn35.94:10.3: Bhikkhus, conquer these passions and aversions
sn35.94:10.4: and go beyond birth and death!”
